headline: Domino's Pizza profit rises 28.7 per cent
text:
Domino's Pizza Enterprises' net profit surged 28.7 per cent to $82.4 million in 2016 but fell short of forecasts due to costs associated with the acquisition of pizza chains in France and Germany during the year.

Excluding costs associated with the purchase of Sprint Pizza in France and Joey's Pizza in Germany, underlying net profit rose 43.6 per cent to $92 million, exceeding guidance for growth of 35 per cent and beating market consensus forecasts by $1 million.

Underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation rose 40.9 per cent to $180 million, compared with guidance around $172 million, as digital technology such as GPS tracking and SMS ordering boosted sales and fattened margins in key markets.

The result highlighted why Domino's major competitors, Pizza Hut and Eagle Boys, are struggling.
summary:
Domino's Pizza Enterprises' net profit surged 28.7 per cent to $82.4 million in 2016 but fell short of forecasts due to costs associated with the acquisition of pizza chains in France and Germany during the year.
Excluding costs associated with the purchase of Sprint Pizza in France and Joey's Pizza in Germany, underlying net profit rose 43.6 per cent to $92 million, exceeding guidance for growth of 35 per cent and beating market consensus forecasts by $1 million.
The result highlighted why Domino's major competitors, Pizza Hut and Eagle Boys, are struggling.
Underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation rose 40.9 per cent to $180 million, compared with guidance around $172 million, as digital technology such as GPS tracking and SMS ordering boosted sales and fattened margins in key markets.
